channel.title: Hmm
channel.description:
Well im wanting to learn a bit more about visual basic, c# and c++
Are there any easy to follow guides u awesome people could recommend?
Thankz
bill

item.title: Hmm
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Best C++ books:
http://jcatki.no-ip.org:8080/fncpp/Resources#books

Note that some are advanced, for starting out, Accelerated C++ or C++ Primer are probably the best.

Though it’s an option (and what I did, in fact), I would recommend against learning C before learning C++, as despite its pseudo-subset nature it will tend to pollute your way of thinking and programming, and changing that mindset will be harder than simply learning the syntax and basic usage of the C++ constructs.

Read full topic

item.title: Hmm
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

even though you are wanting to learn c++, and not c, id recommend K&R’s “The C Programming Language” since it teaches the basics to pointer arithmetic, custom data type declaration (typedef’ing and structures), etc; many of the things that will be useful when learning c++

also, here is a useful tutorial: http://www.cplusplus.com/doc/tutorial/

Read full topic

item.title: Hmm
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I’ve read this, and found it to be a good basis for learning Cpp:

amazon.co.uk

C++ from the Ground Up, Third Edition

This excellent primer provides a plethora of C++ programming information for beginning to intermediate users on topics like classes, objects, expressions, arrays, pointers. Plus, it also covers advanc ...

4.1 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-0072228977, McGraw-Hill Education, 1 Apr 2003, £25.78

Although I have to stress these are not necessarily the best books, merely ones I’ve personally read and can recommend. There’s hundreds to choose from, if needs be you can even watch video tutorials, but in my opinion a book allows you to go at your own pace and is to hand as a reference whenever you need it.

There’s also the sun java online tutorial ofcourse: http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/

Read full topic

item.title: Hmm
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Buy a book off Amazon, but skip learning Visual Basic it’s a waste of time. I’ve got no experience of C#, some people here swear by it, others loathe it. I’d learn C++ or Java first, certainly not more than one at once though.

amazon.co.uk

Java The Complete Reference, Seventh Edition (Osborne Complete Reference Series)

The world's leading programming author offers comprehensive coverage of the new Java release  The definitive guide to Java has been fully expanded to cover every aspect of Java SE 6, the latest versio ...

4.2 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-0072263855, McGraw-Hill Osborne, 1 Dec 2006

This book is actually by my Java lecturer at uni and is due for release sometime this year:

amazon.co.uk

Java: Just in Time

At last -- a first programming in Java course that is truly aimed at students who have not programmed before! (It has an entry point for those who have.) * Using neither the confusing `objects first' ...

4.7 out of 5 stars, ISBN: 978-1848900257, College Publications, 17 Dec 2010, £17.50

Read full topic
